postsData.content:
She left me. 



Because she did not understand my life choices.

I met my friend(15 yrs of knowing each other) after a very long time and she promised to visit me the coming week but ghosted me instead.

While we will come around it reminded me of all the times, I would blame people for not walking out of a situation thinking they always have a choice.

And that is exactly how she felt for me.

But I now appreciate people and understand better that everyoneâ€™s journey is unique, shaped by individual goals, experiences, and challenges.

And that people shouldn't necessarily be expected to understand all our life choices, especially when they come from different perspectives or value systems.

Because at the end of the day, your life choices are yours to make.

Life changes.
People will leave.
Your friends will change.
And with each of these you should too.

P.S- While itâ€™s natural to seek validation from others, what's more important is being confident in your own decisions, even if they don't align with the expectations of those around you.

Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science & Robotics
Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science & Robotics
postsData.content:
DeepSeek vs ChatGPT: Key Differences

1. Developer
DeepSeek AI: Developed as an open-source LLM.
ChatGPT: Proprietary model developed by OpenAI.

2. Model Type
DeepSeek AI: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture.
ChatGPT: Transformer-based (GPT-4).

3. Training Data
DeepSeek AI: Multilingual with a strong focus on Chinese.
ChatGPT: Extensive multilingual training, with strong performance in English.

4. Performance
DeepSeek AI: Efficient and cost-effective, optimized for coding and technical tasks.
ChatGPT: Excels in reasoning, creativity, and text coherence.

5. Strengths
DeepSeek AI: Best for coding, programming, and technical applications.
ChatGPT: Ideal for conversational AI, creative writing, and coding assistance.

[Explore more in the post]

comments.commentText: Thanks Denis Panjuta!

Top Tips for Finding Remote Jobs on Leading Platforms in 2025


The rise of remote work continues into 2025, and finding the right job on platforms like FlexJobs, LinkedIn, We Work Remotely, and AngelList can be a game-changer. Hereâ€™s how to make the most of these sites:

1. Use Custom Search Filters: Narrow down your results by using filters for remote roles, industry, and job type. Set job alerts to stay ahead of new listings.

2. Tailor Your Resume: Highlight remote-specific skills like self-motivation, time management, and virtual collaboration to make your resume stand out.

3. Network on LinkedIn: Connect with hiring managers and fellow remote workers. Join groups focused on remote work for exclusive job leads.

4. Stand Out with Personalization: When applying on sites like We Work Remotely or AngelList, make your cover letter specific to the company and role. Show you understand their mission and remote culture.

5. Prepare for Video Interviews: Practice for virtual interviews by ensuring your tech works and presenting yourself professionally.

6. Develop Remote-Friendly Skills: Be sure your resume includes key skills for remote workâ€”tools like Slack, Zoom, or Asana are highly sought after.

Remote jobs are more accessible than ever in 2025â€”stay proactive, personalize your approach, and embrace the flexibility of working from home! Happy job hunting!

7 powerful techniques to master time management:

Time is slipping through your fingers.

The to-do list grows longer.

Deadlines pile up.

And by the end of the day, you feel like youâ€™ve accomplishedâ€¦ nothing.

Sound familiar?

It doesnâ€™t have to be this way.

Here are 7 powerful techniques to mastering time management:

1/ Eat That Frog

Start your day by tackling your hardest, most important task. Get it done first, and the rest of your day will feel lighter.

2/ The Pomodoro Technique

Work for 25 minutes, then take a 5-minute break. Short bursts of focus beat distractions every time.

3/ The 2-Minute Rule

If a task takes less than 2 minutes, do it immediately. Itâ€™s a small action, but the momentum it creates is massive.

4/ The 1-3-5 Method

Plan your day by tackling:

1 big task.
3 medium tasks.
5 small tasks.

This method prevents overwhelm and keeps you moving forward.

5/ The Eisenhower Matrix

Categorize your tasks:

Do: Urgent & important
Delegate: Urgent but not important
Decide: Important but not urgent
Delete: Neither urgent nor important

This technique makes prioritization simple and effective.

6/ Getting Things Done (GTD)

List every task.

Handle the quick ones right away.
Schedule the rest for when you have more time.

Itâ€™s perfect for long-term clarity and planning.

7/ The Pickle Jar Theory

Imagine your time as a jar. Fill it with the big rocks first - your most important tasks. Sand (distractions) comes last.

Bonus: Task Batching

Group similar tasks and complete them together. Emails, calls, or brainstorming. Handle them all in one focused block of time.

The beauty of these methods?

Theyâ€™re flexible.

Try them.
Mix them.
Find what works best for you.

Because time is not just hours on a clock.

Itâ€™s the currency of your life.

What you spend it on today defines the life youâ€™ll have tomorrow.

- - -

P.S. Whatâ€™s your go-to time management hack?

//ANTI-DROWNING T-SHIRT INNOVATION 

This is Floaty, the first anti-drowning t-shirt.

It's worn like a regular t-shirt, but if a child wearing it accidentally falls into the water without any supervision, it will automatically inflate and keep the child afloat.

This T-shirt is not intended for swimming, but only for emergencies.

In contrast to traditional swimming aids such as swimsuits or armbands, Floaty guarantees the child's return to the surface of the water in less than five seconds.

The soluble tablet is on the t-shirt's side, discreetly under the arm.

When it comes into contact with water, it dissolves automatically, releasing the CO2 that is contained in the capsule.

If the child is rescued, the t-shirt can be reloaded by unscrewing and screwing in a new capsule.

With Floaty, parents can have peace of mind knowing their child is safe in unforeseen circumstances.

The secret to a 35% salary raise vs. 3%? 
(No one talks about this one)

It's NOT confidence or experience.
Itâ€™s psychology.

Iâ€™ve spent years dissecting advanced negotiation tactics.
Hereâ€™s what I learned:

The most powerful moves happen before you even reach the table.

Here's the play-by-play my clients use to land game-changing raises:

1/ The 6-Month Setup
â†³ Plant evidence of your value consistently
â†³ Track & share quantifiable wins weekly

2/ Multi-Layered Influence
â†³ Build a network of advocates across departments
â†³ Get cross-functional leaders invested in your success

3/ Strategic Timing
â†³ Strike after major wins or during growth phases
â†³ Avoid cost-cutting seasons or locked budgets

4/ Emotional Intelligence Play
â†³ Start with genuine appreciation
â†³ Frame success as a partnership

5/ Business-First Mindset
â†³ Never mention personal needs
â†³ Show ROI, not cost

6/ Constraint Discovery
â†³ Ask questions that reveal true blockers
â†³ Understand their hidden limits

7/ Power of Silence
â†³ State your ask, then stop.
â†³ Let them break the silence first.

8/ Loss Aversion Trigger
â†³ Frame rejection as missed opportunity.
â†³ Focus on risk, not gain.

9/ Value Articulation
â†³ Get them to verbalize your worth.
â†³ Build commitment through their own words.

10/ Leverage Position
â†³ Never negotiate from desperation.
â†³ Show confidence in your options.

11/ Strategic Backup
â†³ Always have another opportunity lined up.
â†³ Let them sense your leverage.

The difference between good & great negotiators?

If you ask (and answer) this 1 question before starting cold outreach, you'll be on track to see 2x results from your outbound in 2025. 

 The question is simple:
Does this matter to THEM?

Too often, outbound efforts are built around what we want: to book a meeting, to hit quota, to close the deal. But hereâ€™s the reality: no one cares about your goals unless they align with theirs.

This is where my
approach comes in.

Before you send an email, pick up the phone, or craft a LinkedIn message, stop and ask yourself: â€œAm I talking about what matters most to my prospect?â€

Taking the time to create email copy and phone talk tracks that align with their priorities is critical.

This is not about prospect-specific personalization. This is about RELEVANCE.


ï¸ Hereâ€™s why:

Relevance drives response.

When you speak to the challenges and goals that matter the most to your prospect, youâ€™re no longer interrupting themâ€”youâ€™re engaging them.

Want to stand out in 2025?

Believe me when I say the bar is low and stealing this strategy will help you 2x your results this year.

Most outreach is about the seller: â€œWe offer X,â€ â€œOur platform does Y.â€

Flip the script by focusing on the prospectâ€™s world instead, and you instantly differentiate yourself.

Trust builds faster when your messaging reflects that youâ€™ve done the homework.

In 2025, relevance isnâ€™t just importantâ€”itâ€™s essential.

Buyers are busier than ever, and generic outreach is the quickest way to get ignored.

When your outreach centers on what truly matters to your prospects, you earn the right to their time, their attention, and eventually, their business.

Pronouns was one. DEI preaching â€˜check your privilege, old white man!â€™ was another.

One of the saddest reflections about Novemberâ€™s campaign came from Tim Miller, a Republican â€˜Never Trumperâ€™ who campaigned energetically for Harris/Walz. â€˜We didnâ€™t ask for anything, just to be allowed to add our voices to the campaignâ€™ he observed (Iâ€™m paraphrasing). â€˜But the Left were not on board, undermining the campaign with protests about Gaza outside the DNC.â€™ And if we look at the numbers, it wasnâ€™t that Trump won â€” Democrats lost by alienating swing-voters with these kinds of antics (not just in November, but over the last four years).

Tatiana Becker I think part of it is that the 'other side' have been and are working from a WWE playbook which is comms that's much more dramatic, aggressive, and attention grabbing.

postsData.content:
Why are sales reps so unhappy?

On the surface, most sellers I know have pretty good lives. 

They make great money and have independence in their jobs.

Yet very few of them are happy and fulfilled in their sales careers.

In fact, they are struggling more than ever.

Why exactly is this?

Despite making great money and having freedom and flexibility, most sellers are stressed out, overwhelmed, and struggling with mental health challenges including burnout, anxiety, addiction, depression, and imposter syndrome.

According to the last State of Mental Health in Sales Report, a whopping 71% of sellers rank their mental health as â€œfairâ€ or â€œpoor,â€ up from 43% in 2020.

Is there something going on in sales right now, or does this just come with the territory?

Is the ongoing pressure to perform year after year, and constant comparison to others in a leaderboard driven culture too much to handle?

Or is there something bigger happening in our collective culture?

I believe that thereâ€™s something much bigger happening.

My frienddid a survey a few months ago on LinkedIn where he asked â€œWhatâ€™s the #1 thing missing in your sales game right now?â€

50% of the sellers who responded said â€œpassion.â€

This tracks closely with what Iâ€™m seeing.

Hereâ€™s the #1 reason why sellers are struggling more than ever:

They are focused solely on extrinsic motivators.

Extrinsic motivators are external to you, and include things like money, recognition, achievement, and approval from others.

Sellers believe that happiness will follow success, and so they put their happiness on hold until theyâ€™ve â€œearned it.â€

The truth is that success follows happiness, not the other way around.

Happy people emit an energy that drives clients to like them and want to work with them.

Positive, passionate people attract success.

Especially when they are passionate about helping others!

So is it possible to be happy, even when your results arenâ€™t where you want them to be?

Absolutely, but it takes focusing on Intrinsic Motivators.

Intrinsic motivators are internal, and include the following four areas:

1. Living With Integrity - this means living your values every single day. Which includes trying your hardest at whatever you do.

2. Growth - this requires having ambitious goals that require you to grow and change to achieve them.

3. Connection - Nurturing and spending time on the relationships that matter most in your life

4. Contribution - knowing that the work we do every day is meaningful and serves others.

When you shift from focusing on extrinsic goals to intrinsic goals, everything else improves.

In this training video, I share how to make this shift, and why itâ€™s so important to your long term happiness, fulfillment, and success.

I will personally add to that that Iâ€™ve been a salesman most of my life often my own company and sometimes my own inventionsâ€¦ And I never sell anything that I havenâ€™t tried first and am 100% pleased with.

When the Client Keeps Undoing Your Work...

Imagine you're an electrician. A client calls you to fix their lights. You do the job, everything worksâ€”great.

Then they call you back: â€œHey, I played around with it and it stopped working again.â€ You go back, fix it again.

Then they call you againâ€”â€œI through a hammer on it, itâ€™s out again.â€ Youâ€™d probably think, Why do they keep breaking it?

Why am I even here if theyâ€™re just going to undo my work?

Now, letâ€™s talk about this week Parsha - ×¤×¨×©×ª ×‘×.

Hashem tells Moshe to go to Pharaoh and demand he release the Jews. But hereâ€™s the twistâ€”Hashem also "hardens Pharaohâ€™s heart", making him refuse.

Over and over again, Moshe pleads, Pharaoh resists, another plague comes, and the cycle repeats.

If you were Moshe, wouldnâ€™t you ask, Why am I doing this if Youâ€™re the one making him say no?

The commentators explain: Hashem didnâ€™t just want to free the Jewsâ€”He wanted to change them.

Growth happens through resistance.

If Pharaoh had just given in right away, the transformation wouldnâ€™t have been as deep.

Now, back to business.

As a leader, consultant, electrician, or fractional CMO, youâ€™ll face this too. You fix a problem, and leadership (or the market) undoes your progress.

You guide a team, and they resist change.

You lay out a strategy, but people stick to their old habits.

Itâ€™s frustratingâ€”but thatâ€™s where the real work happens.

The job isnâ€™t just to fix thingsâ€”itâ€™s to help people through the process of change.

Resistance isnâ€™t failure; itâ€™s part of the transformation.

Ever faced a â€œPharaoh momentâ€ in your work?

How did you handle it?
